title: 110_hr5840
content: The "Insurance Information Act of 2008" may be cited as the official title of this legislation. It establishes the Office of Insurance Information. The Office of Insurance Information is established under the "Insurance Information Act of 2008." The Secretary's duties include advising the President and Congress on insurance policy issues, excluding health insurance. The Act also amends title 31 of the United States Code to transfer and insert sections related to the establishment of the Office. The Office of Insurance Information is established under the "Insurance Information Act of 2008" to advise the President and Congress on insurance policy issues, excluding health insurance. The Office of Insurance Information, established within the Department of Treasury, is headed by a Deputy Assistant Secretary appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Deputy Assistant Secretary is responsible for receiving, analyzing, and disseminating publicly available data on all lines of insurance except health insurance, as well as establishing Federal policy on international insurance matters and ensuring compliance with State insurance laws. The Office of Insurance Information, under the Department of Treasury, is led by a Deputy Assistant Secretary appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Deputy Assistant Secretary oversees international insurance policy agreements and advises on major insurance issues, excluding health insurance. The Office of Insurance Information, led by a Deputy Assistant Secretary appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury, oversees international insurance policy agreements, excluding health insurance. State laws are preempted if they conflict with Federal policy on international insurance matters outlined in agreements with foreign entities. The State can appeal any inconsistency determination to the Secretary. States cannot enforce preempted insurance laws. The Deputy Assistant Secretary must report to Congress on the insurance industry's financial state, trends, actions taken, and other relevant information. The Office of Insurance Information may use existing Treasury resources, but does not have general regulatory authority over insurers. An Advisory Group has been established for the Office. The Advisory Group for the Office of Insurance Information consists of up to 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various organizations. The group's duties include making recommendations on the Office's function and determinations. Appropriations are authorized for the Office as needed each fiscal year. The Office of Insurance Information is authorized appropriations each fiscal year. A Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury is added to Section 111 of Public Law 93-495 for independence in Congressional testimony. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subchapter I of chapter 3 of title 31, United States Code. The Office of Insurance Information is authorized appropriations each fiscal year. A Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury is added for independence in Congressional testimony. Terrorism and Financial Intelligence, Office of Insurance Information, and Continuing in office are addressed in the sections 312, 313, and 314 respectively.
